awd_titl_txt: LTREB Renewal: Ecosystem Structure and Function in Palouse Grasslands
awd_abstract_narration:
Grasshopper abundance in the western United States varies dramatically across years and locations. Grasshoppers can have high numbers at one site and low numbers at a nearby site in the same year, while in the next year the numbers at the sites may be reversed. This can create economic hardship for livestock producers that depend on reliable forecasts of both weather and pests. Possible reasons for the large variation in grasshoppers include weather patterns, plant quantity and nutritional quality, and predation. Understanding grasshopper dynamics cannot be advanced by studies of only one possible reason or at a just one site over a few years, but requires long-term studies across a number of sites.   This project will involve a number of graduate students and provide outreach to Federal, State and Tribal agencies, non-governmental organizations and civic groups. The project will also be woven into an established summer field ecology program run by the University of Notre Dame. This program provides 10-week field research experiences to undergraduates and specifically recruits Native American and non-Native students in order to help to promote cultural exchange. The program has been successful in that all of the participating Native American students have completed undergraduate degrees and a number are now working for Tribal natural resource agencies.

While weather cannot be experimentally altered, results from different years and sites will be compared to help disentangle the effects of food and predation on grasshopper populations over a range of weather conditions. Grasshoppers will also be experimentally studied by keeping some populations in large field cages at different sites where plant quality and quantity and predation are manipulated relative to natural levels in any given year. Grasshopper populations can reduce plant production directly through consumption and indirectly through their effects on the cycling of nutrients needed by plants. Results of long term studies thus far indicate that populations at some sites are more frequently controlled by one or the other mechanism, but populations across all sites are not controlled by the same mechanism in any year. This project will add to that long term record in order to answer why one mechanism operates only in some years at certain sites, and also to reveal long-term trends due to climate changes. And while the numbers of larger plant-eating animals, such as bison, elk, deer, or rabbits, may not vary as much as grasshoppers do, they also may be controlled by availability of food at some times and places, or by predation at others. Therefore, the grasshopper system is a model useful for addressing this question more generally.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes Addressing Intellectual Merit:

Bunchgrass prairie, one of the most endangered ecosystems in North America, once covered intermountain valleys from the Rockies west to the Cascades and from southern Alberta/British Columbia south to northern Utah/Nevada, but now is restricted to less than 250,000 acres by agriculture and overgrazing (<1% of original area). This ecosystem once supported a wide array of abundant herbivores from bison to grasshoppers, but in many areas, grasshoppers often were the dominant herbivore (>50% of plant consumption). The food web of bunchgrass prairie plants, grasshoppers, spiders and birds was studied from 1978 – 2019 at the National Bison Range (~25,000 acres in western Montana), one of the remaining bunchgrass prairie areas. These studies included annual monitoring of the weather, soil nitrogen, plants and all herbivores (bison elk, bighorn sheep, mule and whitetail deer, pronghorn, voles, and grasshoppers). In addition, long-term field experiments were conducted to examine the dynamics of the plant, grasshopper, spider and bird food web.

Monitoring indicated long-term changes in the bunchgrass prairie and its herbivores. The prairie vegetation has become more productive as springs have become wetter and cooler; however, the vegetation becomes senescent faster in summer as it has become warmer. In addition, the vegetation has become more dominated by grasses. As would be expected, herbivores that prefer to feed on grasses have increased in abundance (e.g., bison, elk, voles and some grasshoppers), while other species that prefer to feed on forbs have decreased (e.g., deer, pronghorn, and some grasshoppers). These changes appear to be a consequence of anthropogenic climate change.

The experiments provide a number of results that question general ecological concepts:

1)      Sites close to each other can differ as to whether grasshoppers increase the amount of vegetation by speeding up nitrogen cycling or decrease it by slowing down nitrogen cycling. Faster nitrogen cycling occurs when the grasshoppers prefer to feed on plants that decompose slowly, and slower nitrogen cycling occurs when grasshoppers prefer to feed on plants that decompose faster.

2)      Grasshoppers are not consistently limited by predation, as often claimed for herbivores, but vary over time between being limited by predators (<40% of time) and food availability. Predation tends to be limiting when grasshoppers starting the annual cycle are at lower densities, vegetation is at a lower abundance, and plant ground cover is low. This leads to some sites close to each other being more prone to being limited by predation.

3)      Given #1 above, if grasshoppers benefit vegetation at a site, then predator limitation of grasshoppers would be detrimental to the vegetation, while if grasshoppers are detrimental to vegetation, then predator limitation of grasshoppers would benefit the vegetation. Therefore, the role of predation and herbivory on vegetation results in more complex and nuanced food web dynamics than previously considered.

4)      This food web complexity may apply to a range of food webs whether terrestrial or aquatic, or composed of vertebrates or invertebrates, based on a literature survey.

This study indicates the strength of combining monitoring of a field ecosystem along with experiments to understand ecological dynamics.

 

Outcomes Addressing Broader Impacts:

The project involved undergraduate and graduate students, which included Native Americans, African Americans, Hispanics, Asians and a majority of women. Findings from this study have been employed in range and wildlife management, agricultural pest control strategies, conservation and climate change adaptation policies.
